As a result, Snap ha reportedlylow it expectations, and certain estim expect price to come as low as $14-$16 per share, impli a valuat of$16-19bn.makeArticleAd();Ahead of it expect price (anticip onMarch 1st) we take a look at whether the rumor valuat make sense, and provid our own guidanc on where investor should be price the stock.W find that while overal market concern regard DAU growth are justified, the market is like undervalu the company' ARPU growth prospect and conclud that there is signific upsid on the tabl for investors. For us, Snap is a buy.Growth is the answerA mentioned, initi report larg focus on compar Snap' purport valuat to it revenues, which when compar to it peers, admittedli look veri expens (tabl 1).But such an analysi miss the mark complet in two import ways. Firstly, mani of the compani in Snap' peer univers are not directli compar (Googl (GOOG) (GOOGL) is a search compani and Amazon (AMZN) is an onlin retailer, to name a few). Limit the peer univers to Snap' most directli compar peers, Facebook (FB) and Twitter, is a more appropri juxtaposit (chart 1 and 2).But even when just limit one' comparison to Facebook and Twitter, the matur profil of the respect compani are veri differ and must be account for. A fairer analysi would look at the metric pre-IPO for all three (chart 3 and 4). In do so, reader will notic that the rel valuation, albeit still expensive, look less so than in the prior charts.Ther are still time issu with such a comparison though. For reference,Facebook wa eight year old and Twitter wa sevenat the time of their IPOs. Snap is onli five, and with 2-3 more year of growth under it belt, Snap could be a veri differ company.Moreover, Snap is a direct-to-mobil platform while Facebook and Twitter went public in a world in which desktop-deliveri still play a domin role. Consid the shift from desktop to mobile, Snap is enter a market with a grow user base (mobil take share from desktop) on a deliveri platform that is captur increas user engag (chart 5 and 6).In summary, the differ matur profil coupl with the differ deliveri platforms, both now as well as at IPO, make for a troublesom comparables-bas approach when assess Snap' valuation. Snap may look expens when compar to it peers, but compar to it peer is not the right approach.With the abov in mind, a Snap-onli analysi make most sense. And such an analysi should almost sole be focus on one thing: growth. For ani compani at Snap' stage, growth is paramount to valuation, and to thi end, there are fundament two thing that affect growth go forward:1) Growth in Daili Activ User (DAUs), and2) Growth in Averag Revenu Per User (ARPU)W look at these in turn.DAU Growth: Doubt LoomMuch of the more insight analysi which emerg a few week after the file ha in fact focus on DAU growth. And the hawk are out in flock. Unfortun for Snap,whil initi user growth perform wa impress (chart 7), there ha been a signific downtick in new user join the platform in recent months. Despit outperform both Facebook and Twitter in term of user growth in the six quarter lead up to it IPO, Snap saw quarterli growth rate drop from doubl digit figur to onli 7% in Q3 16 and, even more worryingly, to a paltri 3.3% in Q4 16 (chart 8).Management' justif for the follow can be found in their S1, wherethey state:"Th rate of net addit Daili Activ User wa rel flat in the earli part of the quarter end Decemb 31, 2016, and acceler in the month of December. Although we have histor experienc lumpi in the growth of our Daili Activ Users, we believ that the flat growth in the earli part of the quarter wa primarili relat to acceler growth in user engag earlier in the year, diminish product performance, and increas competition.Th rate of net addit Daili Activ User acceler in the first half of 2016 compar to the second half of 2015, larg due to increas user engag from product launch and increas adopt rate among older demograph and intern markets. Thi creat a higher baselin of Daili Activ User head into the third and fourth quarters, so increment net addit within these quarter were more difficult even with strong year-over-year growth. Additionally, in mid-2016, we launch sever product and releas multipl updates, which introduc a number of technic issu that diminish the perform of our application. We believ these perform issu result in a reduct in the growth of our Daili Activ Users, particularli among Android user and region with a higher percentag of Android devices. Finally, we also saw increas competit both domest and intern in 2016, as mani of our competitor launch product with similar function to ours."Th abov explan thu emphas two key potenti caus for the slowdown in growth: technic issu with their Android product, and/or increas competition.Th former,whil problematic, would not be a signific caus for concern. One would think that a compani fund to the tune of $2.6bn and withnearli 2,000 employees(mani of them in engineering) would be abl to solv thi and revert the company' growth cours back to what it wa at the begin of 2016.But the more worri concern revolv around competition. Snap face increas pressur from competitors, particularli Facebook and Instagram, which, if unresolved, could continu to limit DAU growth go forward. In fact, it is no wonder that Snapchat' growth number began suffer in Q3 16 as thi wa exactli when Instagramlaunch Stories, a near-blat copi of Snapchat' namesake.Unfortun for Snap, data regard growth in DAU by geographi onli lend further weight to the competit concerns. In fact, on a geograph basis, much of the slowdown in Snap' DAU appear to have been primarili in the "Rest of World" region (chart 9). Given Instagram' significantli larger user base abroad (80% of Instagram' c.300m DAU are international), one could see how the incent for instal Snapchat diminish as Instagram (and other competitors) begin to offer the key featur that Snapchat ha to-dat sold itself on.To summarize, thing don't look good for Snapchat from a DAU growth perspective. Not onli wa Q4 16 Snap' lowest grow quarter sinc the begin of it publicli avail data, but it wa even slower than that of Facebook, a far more matur compani (chart 10). Given these headwinds, Snap will have to effect convinc investor that it can address it deceler quarter-over-quart DAU growth if it wish to hit the valuat number that have been publicized.Look Ahead: Facebook Growth or Twitter Struggles?With the abov in mind, our expect is that Snap, go forward, will experi a user growth profil more akin to Twitter' than to Facebook's.Whil growth will be sustain by it continu popular in the Unit States, competit from Facebook, Instagram andoth intern competitorswil continu to limit Snap' growth internationally.Our base case expect is therefor for an averag of 14.1% growth per year post-IPO, almost right in between Facebook' and Twitter' annual averag growth rate of 19.1% and 10.3%, respect (tabl 2). The primari sourc of the growth premium to Twitter deriv from Snapchat' abil to innov on product featur better than Twitter (more on thi below).ARPU Growth: Solid Start with Ampl Upsid RemainingWhilst the abov DAU estim are noth for investor to get excit about, and fall larg in line with most market commentary, stop one' analysi at DAU perform is shortsighted. In particular, it miss the key other side of the coin: ARPU. And when it come to ARPU growth, we see a radic differ story. Our view is that Snapchat will see strong ARPU growth go forward, driven by the follow factors:A more monetization-friendli productA more advantag posit with a key user demographicA gener more monetization-focus manag mindsetAl of these will in turn be boost by gener underli strength in the mobil advertis space. We look at these in turn.Snapchat is a veri monetization-friendli productOn of the most attract featur of Snapchat from an ARPU standpoint is that the product itself appear to lend itself veri well, arguabl better than it competitors, to monetization. The effect of the platform is larg driven by Snap' abil to innov on product featur and stay ahead of the competition, and thi ha allow Snap to build impress strong posit in imag share and in video.Look first at imag sharing, Snap ha caught up rapidli with it competitor (chart 11) larg thank to it abil to innov with the format (initi with disappear messages, later with filters, Stories, etc.). The implic of thi is signific in that it ha allow Snap to lead the industri in term of develop and deliv sponsor / brand content for thi type of format. For instance, focus on sponsor filters, Snap' abil to reach a larg audienc far exce Facebook despit it significantli smaller user base (chart 12).The growth in imag share and the innov surround it product featur ha posit Snap favor amongst advertisers, allow Snap to strike import partnership with verysignific brandsworldwide. One of the exampl of such campaign that Snap highlightsin it S1relat to how Wendy' blanket it U.S. store with Sponsor Geofilt that promot the Jalapeño Fresco Chicken Sandwich. Snap' measur tool report that the Sponsor Geofilt drove over 42,000 increment peopl to a Wendy' locat within seven day of view the Sponsor Geofilter.Perhap more import than imag sharing, Snap ha develop a domin posit in video, convert it into aseri threat to Facebook. Accord to theKCPB presentation, as of Q1 16 Snap ha surpass Facebook in term of daili video view despit it significantli smaller user base (chart 13).Thi success to date ha been driven by Snap' uniqu approach to the video format. KCPB refer to Snap approach as "3V Advertising": (1) Vertic - made for mobil viewing, (2) Video - a great way to tell a story, (3) View - alway full screen.Th combin of these three ha made video advertis that much more effect on Snapchat. In fact, accord to the KCPB presentation, outsid of Snapchat mani video ad are ineffect with 81% of peopl mute the ads. However, Snap point out in it S-1 that on average, 60% of all Snap Ad are watch with the sound on.Th abov again point to Snap' effect as a monet platform as well as the manag team' abil to keep innov on product and stay ahead of the curv when it come to marri fun and engag product featur with monet avenues. Arec exampleof success with video would beGatorade' sponsor len dure the Super Bowl, a campaign which led to 60 million play in total, 165 million view and an increas of 8 point in purchas intent.Snap ha develop the ultim trifecta - a robust advertis platform that combin commun (chatting), imag creation and sharing, and video content. Thi ha lead to numer market campaign achiev abov averag industri impact, perform and ROI. Thi should support rapid growth of ARPU as more market recogn these benefit and decid to move advertis dollar over to Snap.Snap is veri strong with a key user demographicA the pool of mobil advertis invest dollar rises, more advertis are look to target Millenni and younger demographics. In 2015, Market dedicatedov a third (34%) of their annual market budgetsto target these groups. That figur wa like even greater with teen and "tweens" included.Th abov phenomenon is larg becaus Millenni are expect to drive consum spend in the year to come. Millenni are80 million strong, the largest demograph in the Unit States, anda of March 2015, also the largest demograph in the workforce.Thi of cours translat into huge spend power. Estim indic Millenni could be spending$1.4 trillion annual by 2020and could inherit as much as $30 billion in the come years. Even teen and tween are gener signific spend power,spend as much as Babi Boomersin 2015.The issu advertis face is that Millenni are move away from tradit advertis channel to their phone (chart 14). Compani like Snap, as well as it competitors, provid an optim channel through which to target these groups.Fortun for Snap, they seem to have develop a veri strong posit in these age-groups. With 63% of Snap user in the 18-34 age category, and 22% between 13-17 year of age, Snap ha captur the attent of a highli covet market demograph (chart 15 - note: chart is from a 2016 comScor report, as such the data doe not perfectli tie with Snap' latest demograph report in it S-1).More importantly, Snap ha becom a lead platform in term of it engag within 18-34 age demograph (chart 16). Facebook is clearli a domin player with massiv reach and signific engagement, but Snapchat is the second lead platform in term of averag monthli minut per visitor. As Snap continu to expand it reach and further penetr thi key age group, Snap should move higher and further to the right on thi chart as it continu to threaten Facebook' leadership.Thi all bode veri well for Snap. The compani ha continu to rapidli expand it reach within the 18-24 categori while also broaden it penetr within older age groups. As of Decemb 2015, accord to comScore, more than three-out-of-f 18-24 year old now activ use Snapchat, with older age group also on the rise (chart 17).With a domin in the Millennial, Teen and Tween demographics, the second lead platform in term of monthli engag and further expans of it reach within each of those key demograph Snap should receiv an outsiz portion of advertis dollar go forward. Thi should support rapid ARPU expans in the come years.Snap manag is more monet focusedPut the abov two tactic point aside, the most encourag thing about Snap is that manag ha consist shown a greater predisposit and knack for convert fun new product featur into monet avenues. In short: Snap manag appear to be excel at monetization.And the result bear thi out. When compar to Facebook and Twitter, Snap start monet earlier, and ha grown faster in term of ARPU than both of it comparables, despit be sever year "younger" as a compani (chart 18 and 19).Admittedly, claim that Snap is simpli better at monet than it comp is a subject and difficult-to-prov assertion. However, if you believ this, then what make thi an even more interest point is when you consid how much upsid could still be left for Snap to capture. To thi end, a simpl side-by-sid comparison of ARPU number with Facebook and Twitter suggest that Snap' ARPU could rise as much as 7x what it is today (chart 20).For us, Snap' impress histor perform in ARPU driven by it clear abil to innov in product and monetization, combin with the tremend upsid still there for the taking, point to strong and rapid catch-up in term of ARPU in the year to come. It is therefor not surpris to us that after havingfail to acquireSnapchat, Facebook ha now revert torepl it featur consistently.Overal Industri Growth will keep support Snap ARPU GrowthAsid from the intrins strength of Snap as a company, it' also obviou that overal underli industri strength will help sustain ARPU growth in the come year (although the extent to which thi will be remain a question).Accord to areport from IDC, ad spend is expect to grow from $652 billion in 2016 to $767 billion in 2020 with mobil specif spend grow 3x from $66 billion in 2016 to $196 billion in 2020. Social media market in particular is expect to grow 20% per year to $50.2bn in 2019,comfort overtakingnewspap advertis by 2020.Moreover,accord to KPCB, there is a $22bn market opportun in mobil advertis as it is the onli grow outlet in term of percent of consumpt time. Thi should continu to encourag market to shift away from more legaci outlet like TV and print and into mobil (chart 21). Given that Snap' entir advertis inventori is on mobile, a grow pool of total mobil advertis dollar will certainli benefit Snap go forward.Rabbit from a hat: Ancillari product launch may add further upsid to ARPUFor further revenu upsid one can't overlook Snap' potenti to develop ancillari products.Snap ha alreadi demonstr a willing to explor new product categori with the launch of Spectacl in Septemb 2016, it first ever hardwar product. New product develop outsid of softwar could potenti provid Snap with a veri interest monet model that is differ from their competitor (FB is explor VR) and a uniqu way of own more of the user' share of mind.Spectacl are wearabl glass with a built-in camera that link seamlessli to a smartphon to creat uniqu Snap from a "human perspective." The compani view Spectacl as an extens of Snapchat and intend to use the glass to creat a uniqu circular format for video as oppos to the standard rectangular view perspect (onc again reinvent the standard video deliveri model).Spectacl do gener revenu for Snap, but for 2016 the revenu were not materi and, thus, not report in the company' filing. Go forward, Spectacl could repres a much larger portion of Snap' revenue.It' unclear what other type of new product Snap is plan to bring to market, but Snap ha demonstr a strong abil to creat innov and sticki product that drive increment user growth and revenu (chart 22). Expect each new product introduct to be strateg in drive user growth, enhanc user engagement, and increas share of mind, all thing that should bring creat even greater revenu opportun for Snap.ARPU Growth Go Forward: A Monet MachineLook ahead and given all of the above, our expect is that despit slow user growth, Snap' platform should support veri strong ARPU growth go forward. We see Snap' ARPU catch up with Facebook' in the next five years, and it would not surpris us if it surpass it further out. In other words, despit Twitter-lik user growth, Snap is like to experi more of a Facebook-like, if not better, ARPU growth profile.Th biggest risk to thi scenario play out mainli relat to Facebook and other competitors' abil to replic Snap' featur both quickli and effectively. Should thi be the case, Snap' leadership in product innov will like fail to spill over into signific ARPU growth. However, should competitor struggl to play the "catch-up game" well enough, Snap will like see ARPU growth rate in line with what we predict below. The latter ha been interestingli describ as the "Gingerbread strategy" inthi article.With that in mind we anticip two possibl ARPU growth trajectories. Our downsid case project are more in line with other commentari and essenti consid the latter scenario of product innov follow by effect catch-up by competitors. The base case is instead predic on management' abil to keep innov on product, and competitors' rel ineffect at copi such features.Th number of both case are display in tabl 3 below, but the highlight is that in our base case projections, we anticip north of 50% CAGR over the next five years, with ARPU catch up to Facebook' 2016 number by 2019/2020.Put Thi All Together: What is Snap worth?With all of the abov in mind, we can now proceed to calcul our estim valuat for Snap. We first look at what Snap' revenu will look like go forward, base on our DAU and ARPU assumpt outlin above, and then move into a valuat analysi use these revenu estimates.Financi ForecastsOur financi forecast are summar in Tabl 4, but the headlin number we want to highlight are the following:DAU growth in between Twitter and Facebook' post-IPO performance, reach 246 million DAU by 2019Strong ARPU catch-up and growth, reach $6.88 per user by 2019, nearli equal Facebook' current 2016 ARPU numbers, in the Base CaseMor limit ARPU growth in the Downsid Case, reach $4.80 by 2019, in line with Twitter' current ARPU numbersTot Revenu of $1.6 billion and $3.8 billion achiev in 2017 and 2018, respectively, in the Base CaseTot Revenu of $1.3 billion and $2.7billion achiev in 2017 and 2018, respectively, in the Downsid CaseValuationW valu Snap on an EV / Revenu basi use a target multipl rang of 6.0x to 10.0x deriv from the midpoint of the rang between Facebook and Twitter current trade multiples. column1: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Will Try to Dominate India
column3: InvestorPlac - Stock Market News, Stock Advic & Trade TipsWhil China' e-commerc market is still growing,Alibaba Group Hold Ltd(NYSE:BABA) and it affili Ant Financi are alreadi look south to India. Last year, Morgan Stanley predict that theIndian e-commerc marketwould grow the fastest globally, to $119 billion by 2020. And Alibaba stock is pois to benefit.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockWhat' drive e-commerc and fintech in India? India pass the U.S. as the world' No. 2 smartphon market last year, with 220 million user . T he number of smartphon user in India is expect to balloon to 810 million by 2021 and India' 3G and 4G network could cover 300 million subscrib by March 2018.India' young and grow popul is increasingli tech-savvy, especi millennials.India' govern also support a cashless economy, see thi as a way to reduc corrupt and tax evasion. The Indian govern alsoremov the largest banknotes, 500 rupe and 1000 rupe notes, from the economy. Thi led to an explos in the use ofmobil wallet in India, ad as mani as 1 million user ad per day .Last year, the Nation Payment Corpor of India announc theUnifi Payment Interface, make it conveni for Indian to access their bank account on their phone and pay.And all these move part flow into the bull case for Alibaba stock.Tak Ant' Strategi to IndiaAlibaba and Ant (formerli Alipay) invest inOne97Communications, the parent compani of Indian e-commerc player Paytm. They are expect to increas their stake to 50% from 42%. Paytm last year spun off it payment busi to compli with regulations. One97 hold a 49% stake in Paytm Payment Bank and Paytm founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma own 51%.Paytm boasted177 million usersat the end of the year and CFO Madhur Deora ha set a medium-term target of 500 million user . That growth would be a boost for Alibaba stock and Ant Financi which seeks2 billion user worldwideov the next decade.7 Best Stock to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightPaytm is clearli take a page out of Alibaba and Ant Financial' playbook. Like BABA'sMyBank- the bank "for the littl guy" - Paytm' bank promis to be a vehicl for financi inclusion, bring servic to India' unbanked.Lik Ant, Paytm also want to offer loan andasset manag servicesto those who can't access them now.Ant Fortune, a wealth manag app, debut in 2015. It user can put money in Yuebao, a money market fund, and invest inZhao Cai Bao, where they can loan money directli to businesses.Paytm' Threat to BanksBank in both countri are threaten by thi disruption. Ant' Yuebao offer depositor higher interest rate than bank andinst withdrawals. Technolog compani don't have to maintain as mani employe at branch as bank do, and can link borrow and saver directly. Their asset-light model is simpli more effici than that of exist banks, which have to use their own capital, and are burden by legaci system and regulation.Bank earn a profit on the spread, the differ between the rate at which they lend and the rate they offer depositors. Platform that connect borrow and lender and cut out the middleman can exert pressur on this. And becaus Paytm and Ant Financi are branchless, they have lower overhead costs, and can offer lower fee than banks.Paytm will be both a friend and a potenti enemi to banks. It will help them drum up busi by cross-sel their servic to it users. But Paytm will probabl be the front-end in custom interact and releg the bank to the back end .Bank risk becom "dumb pipes." As I mention inmi articlelast year, the front-end gener give bank a higher return on equiti than the back. AMcKinsey & Companystudi found that bank earn a 22% return on equiti from sale and origination, but onli 6% from the extens of credit.Protection RisksAl of thi doesn't mean that the success of Alibaba, Ant and Paytm is guaranteed. Some risk still stand in the way.First, protectionist sentiment is rise in India asAmazon.com, Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) andUberclobb their Indian rivals. Indian startup such as Flipkart, Snapdeal (in which BABA is an investor), and Ola have had their valuat repeatedli mark down over the past year. Now some are ask for protect against supposedli unfair foreign competition. Indian ventur capitalist Vani Kola of Kalaari Capit call for such measures, follow bysimilar sentimentfrom the founder of e-commerc player Flipkart and Ola, view as India' home-grown Uber) .Sinc Paytm is an Indian company, whi would thi be a concern? While Paytm is Indian, it largest sharehold are Chinese, Alibaba and Ant. Would India want such a compani control someth as critic as it payment infrastructure? Expert have rais concern overPaytm user dataend up in server outsid of India.Point to Paytm' Chines ties, the chief minist of West Bengal, Mamata Banerje accus the prime minist ofcompromis nation security. Now, oil and natur ga are slightli better than half those prices.Needless to say, the past coupl of year have been tough on KMI in particular and the U.S. energi patch in general. But there is a turnaround under way. Rig count in the U.S. are up, week after week. The economi is get back on it feet. Thing are look up.And even if thi increas product keep price low, it doesn't matter to KMI. It will be make money on the increas flow, not the prices. Thi is whi the midstream sector is the best place to get back into the U.S. energi game, sinc it' about increas demand and is slightli agnost about supply.Thi Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Trade Is a Sure ThingWhil KMI doesn't throw off a huge MLP-like dividend, it doe provid a 2.3% dividend that will at least pay you for your patienc as the stock and the sector get back to full capacity.Richard Band'sProfit Investingadvisori servic help retir saver outperform the market without lose a minut of sleep along the way. column1: Snap IPO: Exploring the Company's S-1
column3: Snap(NYSE: SNAP) , the social media compani behind Snapchat, ha express interest in an IPO for months, but recent took signific step toward make that a reality.In thi episod ofIndustri Focus: Tech, Motley Fool tech analyst Dylan Lewi and contributor Evan Niu, CFA, wade through the company' S-1 and breakdown the busi for investors. That' right -- they think these 10 stock are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor return as of Februari 6, 2017Thi podcast wa record on Feb. 16, 2017.Dylan Lewis:Welcom toIndustri Focus, the podcast that dive into a differ sector of the stock market everi day. It' Friday, Feb. 17, and we'r talk tech and explor Snap' IPO filing. I'm your host, Dylan Lewis, and I'm join on Skype byfool.comsenior tech specialist Evan Niu. Evan, how' it going?Evan Niu:Pretti good, pretti good.Lewis:Ar you a Snapchat user? Do you have it on your phone?Niu:I recent download it just to play around with it. I'v read plenti about it, I know how it works, I know the gist of it. But I start play around with it, and it' realli not intuit or easi to use. [laughs] I don't have a lot of peopl on there that I follow, so I certainli don't have the full experi of regular users. But I don't realli see the appeal to it. It seem realli nich to me.Lewis:Yeah, I'll say, I am a Snapchat user. I have a lot of friend that use it. My interest will wane depend on how often my friend are use it, and that will bring me in or out of the system. But, it seem to be super popular with millennials, and given a lot of the buzz with the compani and the fact that it is a big tech compani that' think about go public, there are a lot of investor that are interest in it.Niu:Yeah, there' been so much hype around thi thing. It doesn't seem to me like it ha a mainstream appeal, which is the exact problem thatTwitter(NYSE:TWTR) ha run into over the past few years. I see a lot more closer comparison to Twitter thanFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) , which is the exact opposit storylin that Snap is go to tri to sell do it roadshow.Lewis:Yeah. Listeners, to give you an idea of what we'r go to talk about today, give you a littl overview of Snap, the Snapchat properti specifically, talk a bit about their plan to go public, and what Evan and I notic when we dug through the S-1 that recent becam available. So, we talk about, they are social media company, but they call themselv a camera company, which is interesting.Niu:I notic thi realli funni coincid -- I don't know if you would call it a coincid -- Snapchat use to consid itself a storytel company, and now it' call itself a camera company. Meanwhile,GoPr to call itself a camera compani and now is tri to call itself a storytel company. So, these two companies, they have thi weird ident thing where they want to be each other, and I don't get why, becaus it' not like GoPro is do veri well. I think it' kind of a weird thing rebrand themselv as a camera company. I mean, they have the new Spectacl glass with cameras, but I don't know. It' just a weird ident to me.Lewis:Yeah. For listen who might not be familiar with the social media platform Snapchat, basically, you can think of it as a messag platform where you are, for the most part, shoot quick, instantli delet pictur and video to you and your friends. You can also post them as stories. It ha gain a lot of popular with the millenni group. User count is still kind of low, we can talk about that a littl bit, but the compani is plan to go public, look to rais $3 billion via the public market in an issuanc that would valu the whole compani a somewher between $20 [billion] to $25 billion. As tech IPO go, thi might be one of the biggest one for 2017.Niu:Yeah, definitely. It' definit the most exciting, the most look forward to. Peopl have been wait for thi thing for years.Lewis:Yeah, and anyth that' consumer-fac is natur go to have a lot more buzz to it. I think there might be some folk out there who are saying, "Wait a minute, I thought I saw an announc that thi compani plan to IPO back in the fall of 2016. Whi are we just get the S-1 and all the inform about the compani in the past coupl weeks?" That' becaus Snap opt to go public via the confidenti IPO process. Thi process and thi approach is a byproduct of the 2012 Jumpstart Our Busi Act. Basically, under thi updat legislation, compani with under $1 billion in annual revenu can file paperwork for an IPO confidenti with the SEC. That allow the compani to go back and forth with the regulatori agenc without alert the public that they are plan on IPO-ing, although Snap chose to do so anyway. Then, onc the compani decid they do want to go forward with an issuance, the file must be made public at least three week prior to the IPO roadshow beginning, which is when the underwrit invest bank begin talk to client and build interest in a potenti issuance. Thi is all to say, while the "confidenti IPO" name might sound kind of shady, thi is someth that' total on the up-and-up. And that is the reason whi we onli got a look at the company' book and the S-1 earlier thi month, even though they announc intent to IPO a way back.Niu:Right. I think part of the purpos is to, like you mentioned, avoid public scrutini for the earli draft of the S-1. All compani alway have to file the S-1, but thi way they can refin it without all the public scrutiny, look at it and scrutin it. I think the idea is to encourag more compani to explor the IPO process, and if compani do end up go public, they get more capital, and it just boost the economi in term of more invest happening. I think that' the goal. But, yeah, it is a littl weird when you hear "confidential."Lewis:Yeah, and I think it also give compani the opportun to mayb think about go public and walk back without share all of their busi inform publicly. So, you can test the water and see if you'r ready, and you might decid you'r not, but you don't have to go through the question of your busi practices, if you think you'r go to file and you have to publicli walk back.Niu:Right, exactly.Lewis:So, that' part of it. There are some adjust in the regulatori requir for how far back a compani need to provid financi statements, as well. But really, all in all, it' a tool that allow small-grow compani to keep some of their core busi info privat and make the going-publ process a littl bit easier. And that' realli all there is to the confidenti IPO process. Given that the company' S-1 file becam public earlier thi month, I think it' fairli safe to assum we'r go to see Snap trade on the New York Stock Exchang sometim in the next coupl months. Evan?Niu:Yeah, seem like it' coming.Lewis:Consid that they are a social media company, I think it make the most sens to start look at their user base and what' go on there. That' kind of the lifeblood of busi like Facebook and Twitter, and Snap is realli no different. Within their S-1, they mention, "We assess the health of our busi by measur daili activ user becaus we believ that thi metric is the most reliabl way to understand engag on our platform." So, it' clear that thi is what they'r hone it on as a key metric, and it' what investor are go to be watch as well.Niu:Yeah. I did find it interest that they don't disclos monthli activ users, they onli disclos daili activ users, which is right around 160 million. With social media companies, I alway tend to look at sequenti growth as oppos to year-over-year growth, becaus with user base, that' the nature, there' no seasonality, it' just how much you can grow over time. So, I look at sequential. In that respect, Snap' growth is realli deceler -- it' grind to a halt, almost. And the compani tri to explain thi in saying, "Oh, it' becaus we haven't come out with ani big new product innovation." And, of course, that ha an impact, but you also have to worri about competition, becaus Facebook ha done a realli good job copi a lot of Snapchat' features, especi the Stori thing, which is now on Instagram. Facebook alreadi has, I think, about 150 million daili activ user use Stori now. And they launch that last year, and it' an exact replica. So, you have to wonder if that' what' take a bite out of it. And, obviously, Facebook is much bigger, they have more resources, they can innov and develop faster. It' realli Mark Zuckerberg, and Silicon Valley' -- I mean, Snapchat isn't base in Silicon Valley, but Facebook certainli is -- and Facebook tri to buy them, and if they can't buy them, they'll copi them, and they compete, and that' exactli what they'r doing. And they'r do a realli good job so far. So, I think there is some concern about competit and whether or not Snap can realli keep up.Lewis:Yeah. And Facebook famous made Snapchat an offer, I believ it wa somewher around $5 billion or so, a littl way back, and CEO Evan Spiegel said, "No, we'r go to see what we can do with thi on our own." If they wind up go public at thi gaudi valuation, it certainli work out well for him, but you wonder if that might have stoke the competit fire in Mark Zuckerberg a littl bit.Niu:And he can also empathize, becaus he did the exact same thing withGoogle(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) . [laughs] So mani peopl tri to buy Facebook, and he said, "No, I want to do my own thing," and now Facebook is enorm and he is one of the richest men in the world. [laughs]Lewis:Yeah it' hard to blame him for that. To put some number on what' go on with their user growth, like you said, year-over-year, the number look realli great. They'r up 48%. But sequentially, Q3 to Q4 of 2016, growth wa onli 3%. So, if you look at the graph that they provid in their S-1, it doe look like growth is flatten out a littl bit. Given that so much of the expect for these social platform is continu to build user base, and be abl to monet that user base realli well, you have to worri about that as an ongo risk for the business.Niu:Yeah. If they are a nich product, which, it seem that way to me, then thi could be it...and, obviously, 160 million daili user is a pretti big number. And you can build a healthi busi there if you keep your expect modest and tri to build around that base. Whereas, if you'r tri to grow, if you'r spend a ton of money tri to grow it, and you can't, which is exactli the problem that Twitter is having, then that' when it start to hurt financially. But if you just accept it for what it is and plan your busi accordingly, you can build a pretti decent busi out of it.Lewis:Yeah. For some context, I went back and look at Facebook' S-1 to see how they stack up when they went public. At the time, they had 480 million daili activ users, and they were post 48% year-over-year growth and 6% sequenti growth. You hear that and think, "Well, those growth rate are kind of similar, right?" The differ wa scale. Even when they were do single-digit sequenti growth quarter-to-quarter, they were still ad ten of million of users, not five million, as Snapchat did last quarter. I think that' a huge risk, especi as you see a more entrench competitor take what' work for you and ha a lot of traction with user that you alreadi have on your platform and just appli it to thi massiv user base that they have.Niu:Right. Facebook is interest becaus they start earlier, befor the realli big rise of mobile. So a lot of their earli day were on desktop. Then, they had to navig the transit to mobile, which they have done ridicul well, far better than I think anyon ever imagined, wherea compani like Twitter and Snap, they came out on mobil from the beginning. Particularli Snap -- I mean, there is no desktop Snapchat.Lewis:Right. Beyond the user base, I think a lot of peopl want to know what' go on with the financi as well. In 2016, the compani book $404 million in revenue, up from $58 million in revenu in 2015. That is humong growth, but that is on a veri tini denominator. The realiti with Snapchat is that they realli just kind of turn on the monet engin there, and have onli realli roll out ad for a veri short period of time. Right now, even, it' still a pretti ad-light experi for users.Niu:Yeah. They onli recent releas their API to autom ad sales, which is a huge import part of scale for advertis businesses, becaus it allow your advertis to do thi automatically, it' much less labor-intens to do it. So, they liter onli did thi a few month ago, and it' still in beta. So, it' veri earli day in term of their ad business.Lewis:And that' realli what' go to be make up most of the money for Snap overall, right? Advertis made up 96% of Snap' revenu in 2016. I don't expect that to change. We talk about how they have the Spectacl as well, and they bill themselv as a camera company. There might be some hardwar applic somewher down the road, but in term of a scalable, high-margin business, they'r go to look to monet the Snapchat platform first, becaus if they can do it well, the opportun is the biggest there.Niu:Oh, absolutely. You can't make money on hardware. Those glasses...y might make a littl bit of money, but the whole point of that is to get peopl to use the platform.Lewis:Exactly, yeah. And that just feed into the idea of peopl post their stori and send stuff to friends, and make that video and pictur captur a littl bit easier. Look down at their bottom line, they ran a $500 million loss in 2016, down even more from loss of $370 million in 2015. The compani is also free cash flow neg to the tune of $670 million. No surpris there. It' a high-growth tech company, veri rare are they profit when they go public. But one thing, I don't want to nitpick too much with costs, but one line item that pop out to me wa gener and administr expens are $165 million, which is more than they spent in sale and marketing, and almost as much as the compani spent in R&D. And they talk about how thi is attribut to headcount increas 200% year over year, but from a corpor strategi perspective, it seem like there' sink a ton of money into G&A. I would think, if anything, the big money suck would be on the tech side, and gain talent and push the platform in a new direction.Niu:Particularli with them talk about how import product innov is to drive user growth, you would think they would invest more in that. But yeah, overall, I'm not too surpris at their cost in term of their oper expenses. I just don't know what they'r go to do next to tri to realli grow the platform more. Whi aren't they spend more money on R&D?Lewis:Yeah. And they'r go to have to. If you look at the current valuation...w talk about how they'r probabl go to end up IPO somewher in the $20 [billion] to $25 billion valuat range. That would mean that they are trade at 62X trail sales. Not earnings, sales. That is a huge number.Niu:Yeah, it' ridiculous. I rememb when Twitter and Facebook went public a few year back. They both went probabl right around 25-26X sales. And back then, I wa like, "Wow, that' realli expensive." [laughs] And now, 62X sales, it' unheard of. It just speak to the hype around thi company. Of course, the valuat is go to change, and we don't know what they'r actual go to price the IPO at. Right now, everyth is realli preliminary, and they don't price the IPO until the night befor it actual goe public. And, of course, that' all a function of how success the roadshow is. If they can realli drum up investor interest, or conversely, if they don't, then that' go to realli drive what the IPO price is at. But there' a possibl that thi goe higher if they have a realli good roadshow, which is insane. Can you imagin them get closer to 70X sales? Who know at thi point -- it' not imposs for that to happen. It' just insan that thi compani would be abl to command such a premium.Lewis:And I think anoth layer of context here: Were it to IPO and have a valuat somewher in the mid 20s, it would basic be valu at twice Twitter' current valuation. Accord to analysts, Snapchat ha more daili activ user than Twitter, but Twitter brought in 5X as much revenu last year. So, when you think about what a realli success ad launch would look like, and build out the platform in a way that ha non-invas ad that don't realli detract too much from user experience, and you start to get into that $2.5 billion annual ad revenue, and build on that. And they would be do that at twice the valuat that Twitter is current at. So, you just look at the numbers, and it' realli tough to make it work, the way it' current priced.Niu:Yeah. There' no way I'm touch thi thing. [laughs]Lewis:Beyond valuat and some of the user growth issues, I know that you particularli want to hone in on some of the stuff with vote right with the share they'll actual be issuing.Niu:Yeah, I think it' realli interesting. The share that they'r issu to the public get zero votes. Not even one, zero. A lot of tech compani have been do thi thing for a long time where they give the public share one vote, and the insid get these supervot share with 10 vote or more. That allow the compani founder and insid to maintain control no matter what. Googl is probabl the biggest and earliest exampl of this. Even today, collectively, all the insiders, between the execut and director of Google, they collect control about 60% of the vote power. So, public investor realli have no say. If they disagre with something, they have no recourse. Facebook is, of course, anoth good example, with Zuckerberg himself person control about 60% of the vote power. So, he wouldn't even have to ask anyone, he just doe whatev he wants. So, the question is, is it realli a big deal? Investor are now use to thi idea that they don't get a say and how these compani are run. The differ with Snap is that they'r basic be upfront and be like, "You don't even get to pretend like you have a say."Certainly, it' all bad from a corpor govern perspect on principle, becaus obviously, it' better for sharehold to have a say. But at the same time, you can see that it' work quit well for compani like Googl and Facebook. Imagin if Googl sharehold had a vote in tell Googl not to do all thi random side stuff that they explore, you could argu that the compani wouldn't be as success as it has. There is a case to be made that thi is a good thing, in some situations. But we don't know how it' go to play out for Snap.Lewis:Yeah. I think one of the reason whi I have a bone to pick with it is, you have the two compani co-founders, Evan Spiegel, the CEO, and Robert Murphy, the CTO. They are the sole owner of the supervot Class C shares, which get 10 votes. Ani Class Bs or Cs that are sold are transfer automat convert to the Class As, the non-vot shares. Anyth that would happen with them, they have a supermajority, and anyth that might happen would continu to concentr that power. So, you look at these tech compani later on issu non-vot shares, or with Facebook, decid that they want to split it stock and issu C share so that Mark Zuckerberg can retain hi control of the compani and be abl to give away the non-vot share through hi charit efforts. Mark Zuckerberg ha demonstr that he ha the right combin of that tech-forward think and the busi savvi in order to run one of the world' biggest compani and do it incred successfully. Spiegel and Murphi don't have that track record.Niu:Right. Zuckerberg ha definit earn some respect. He' realli demonstr that he can execut on these bigger-pictur strategi and grow Facebook in the way that he has. The stock split thing is funni because, like you were saying, he vote it in personally, single-handedly. It doesn't matter if you didn't like the stock split, which hasn't actual occur yet even though it' been approved, becaus he said it would happen. But, yeah, you realli need to trust these founders. And Spiegel is 26 or 27. Of course, Zuckerberg wa too, a few year back. But, to your point, he just doesn't have a track record. And it' like, what ha he done beyond creat Snapchat? You can't realli point to ani singl great busi move and be like, "That wa a realli smart strategy, that wa a realli good move." You know? You have to have a lot of faith.Lewis:On of the other thing I'm see a lot of peopl talk about, dig through the S-1 and do their homework on the company, is the company' cloud strategy.Niu:Yeah, thi is realli an interest topic for me becaus Snapchat is do someth that' realli unpreced in term of how they'r approach their cloud infrastructure. Most of the time, when compani are launch these app and onlin servic and consumer-bas products, eventually, when they get to a certain point, they start invest in their own infrastructure, either by build their own data center and server in co-loc facil that they share with other companies, or build their own. Facebook is build it seventh data center, and it' fulli owned. Twitter co-loc it data centers. Snap is not do ani of that. Snap is reli 100% on third-parti cloud infrastructur providers, Googl Cloud andAmazonAWS. It' just crazi becaus the scale at which they'r operating, it would normal make sens to start invest in it yourself, but Snap is content to basic continu to do thi through third parties. It' not clear if thi is go to work, becaus no one ha ever tri thi before, so it' thi huge experiment, and there are a lot of risk becaus you don't get to control your infrastructur in your back end, which is incred import to your business, and you'r also spend a ton of money. Obviously, build the infrastructur yourself cost a ridicul amount of money. But over time, it will eventu pay for itself.So, what Snap is do is that they commit to spend $3 billion total over the next five year between Googl and Amazon combined. Googl is the primari provider, and Amazon is basic a backup. They'r spend $400 million a year on Google. The spend commit with Amazon ramp up, it start at like $50 million and then it' $350 million by the end. But that' a huge spend commitment. Thi is, veri specifically, their largest cost. If you look at their financials, the cost revenu is predominantli compos of these infrastructur costs, and cost revenu is greater than revenue. So, they have a neg gross margin right now becaus of thi strategi veri specifically. At the same time, becaus of these long-term commitments, the pressur is now on for the ad business. You have to grow ad sale to these level just to keep up with it, just to break even on gross profit, befor you even start talk about oper expenses.Th pressur to grow the ad busi is incred high, and they have almost no experi do that. So, it' a huge risk not onli operationally, but it' also a huge risk financially. If you are unabl to grow your ad busi enough to cover these costs, you'r just go to be hemorrhag cash. And it doesn't matter how popular the servic is, if you'r just blow through money and you can't bring in enough to cover these costs, it' not sustainable. We don't know if they'll be abl to do it or not, but the point is, the risk that' there is insane. They have to realli turn up these ad sale just to cover their spend commitments.Lewis:Yeah, beyond all of the gener investor interest in Snap that will undoubtedli be there for the next coupl year and beyond, I think there will be a lot of tech insid watch thi decision. If it works, mayb they'll use it as a blueprint, and decid that it allow the compani to be more nimble. But, you have to wonder about the company' abil to control costs, and have total control over what' go on with the IT infrastructure, becaus that' how everyon is interact with their product.Niu:Yeah. Everyon in the cloud infrastructur market is watch veri closely, becaus they'r like, "Thi is crazy, how much thi compani is spending." It' great news for the cloud infrastructur market, of course, becaus it' one of the biggest custom out there. They'r bring in a lot of money, and everyon is go to see if thi can realli work. I mean, it' worth note that Snap is hedg itself say it might eventu -- in the S-1, it say they may choos to invest in it infrastructur at some point. A few month ago, they actual poach Amazon' head of data center for AWS. So, it' like, there are some hint that they'r explor the idea of do their own infrastructure. But, at the same time, it probabl wouldn't be for the next five year becaus of these commitments. So, yeah, they'r still leav themselv an out. But it seem realli risky. It might work out great. In the event that thing go down -- let' say the servic just crash -- that doe let them ramp down variabl cost with more flexibility, as oppos to, if you spend all thi money to build all thi infrastructur and the servic die for whatev reason, theoretically, then you would be stuck with all thi infrastructur you paid all thi money for. Versus, just pay it as a variabl expens base on usage. So, it' go to be someth that' go to be veri interest to see play out, not just becaus of Snap, but also becaus of the implic for the bigger compani that are provid these servic like Amazon and Google, alsoMicrosoft. Microsoft would certainli like to get a piec of that spending. But yeah, I think that ha a lot of implic for the broader infrastructur market.Lewis:To bring it back around to the stock itself and how we'r look at it, it seem like you and I are in the same camp here -- we have some concern over user growth, the valuat as it' current be reported, we'll see what happen after they run through the roadshow, but the valuat is a littl too rich for us to realli even look at too much, also we have a lot of question about the competit risk with some Facebook and Instagram loom out there, and possibl be abl to just grab featur and drop it on their instal base. Doe that wrap how we feel about Snap? Anyth els you want to add in there, Evan?Niu:I don't think Snap' investable, honestly. There are so mani risks, the financi don't make sense, the valuat doesn't make sense, you get no voting. [laughs] I don't doubt that share will pop from the offer just becaus of the hype, but as we'v seen with mani overhyp IPO in recent years, it onli take a few month for the market to sober up. Plus, Snap' also do a differ thing with the lock-up period. Employe will be abl to sell sooner -- the lock-up expir for employe sooner than is typical. Normally, it' about 180 days. They'r go to allow their employe to sell at 150 days, along with all the co-founders. So, there could be some sell pressur as all these investor and employe cash out. The employe and all the insid are go to make a ton of money, but as far as public investor go, I don't know. It' also worth mention that their stock-bas compens expens so far are quit small becaus they'r still private. I think last year it wa someth like $30-some million, which is a tini proport of their expenses. But when compani go public, the liquid event trigger a ridicul increas in stock-bas compens cost becaus now that stock is worth so much more. And that' typic for all compani that go public -- right after they go public, they have a huge increas in stock-bas comp. That' someth to be awar that is coming. Plus, they'r probabl go to start unload pretti quickly. I don't know, I just don't see, after the initi honeymoon, how thi thing can realli go even further, after it' alreadi at such a ridicul level. You know what I mean?Lewis:I am absolut with you. Listeners, you can be sure that as detail start to crystal and we get a better sens of what' happen with the Snap IPO, we'll be sure to do an updat on thi episod as market condit clear up a littl bit. Or, it wasn't anyway. Thi week, Qualcommunveil it 802.11ax technology, which can carri four time the amount of data current Wi-Fi technolog carries, but without use ani more bandwidth.Qualcomm Technolog VP Rahul Patel explained:It is take Wi-Fi to a new level from a user-experi point of view. What it is tri to do is prepar the Wi-Fi network, which in mani case is experienc a lot of congestion, larg becaus the network is becom dens and is not abl to deal with the amount of traffic.At the same time, the compani ha creat a whole new kind of RF "front end," or the radio connect between a mobil phone' modem and the transceiver. Not onli is it a superior solut to current alternatives, it' a simpler solut that work with a varieti of connect protocols, such as LTE and MIMO, by the util of modem intelligence.They'r not the kind of advanc the averag consum care about, or even understands. column1: Will Your Next New Car Help Build Maps for Self-Driving?
column3: Mobiley N.V.(NYSE: MBLY) , an Isra compani that special in advanc driver-safeti systems, ha begun roll out a new offer that will help the self-driv car of the near futur function in more area -- and your next new car might be enlist to help.Th new offering, call Road Experi Management, or "REM," is a system that will creat highli detail map that self-driv car can use to back up (or double-check) the input from their sensors. It will use data collect by camera on mani new cars, start with the 2018 model year.Thi is a big deal, not just for Mobiley but also for it custom -- which includ nearli all of the world' automak -- and peopl who are hope to have access to self-driv car in the near future.makeArticleAd();Mobileye' chief technolog officer, Amnon Shashua, outlin the company' approach to self-driv in a present last month. Imag source: Mobiley N.V.The problem: Self-driv car need special mapsWhen the first fulli self-driv car arriv on the market in a few years, their capabl will be limited. In most cases, the car will be "geofenced," restrict to drive in particular areas. (In the wide use industri nomenclature, these are call "Level 4" systems. "Level 5" system that are self-driv with no restrict are probabl still mani year away.)Th car will be geofenc becaus most of the self-driv system under develop requir special high-definit map to work safely. The map help the car' "brain" figur out exactli where it is rel to thing like curb and road barriers, provid a layer of redund beyond the car' sensors. (That may sound, well, redundant. But it' critic to ensur that self-driv system meet the requir standard of safety.)Obviously, the compani that can access the best and most extens map will have a competit advantage. Car equip with their system will be abl to drive themselv to more places. That mean that the race is on not onli to creat map cover the widest possibl areas, but to creat way to ensur that the map are alway up to date.Mobiley ha a direct stake in thi race. It' gear up to bring aLevel 4 system to market by the end of 2019, in partnership withDelphi Automotive(NYSE: DLPH) andIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) . That system will be market to automakers, who will probabl be abl to have it in showroom (or in servic with ride-hail companies) by about 2021.Thi self-driv test vehicl incorpor a prototyp of the system be develop by Delphi, Mobileye, and Intel. Imag source: Delphi Automot PLC.The partner will almost certainli have competit from compani likeAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Waymo unit,Ford Motor Company's(NYSE: F)Argo AI subsidiary-- and like others.Mobileye' Road Experi Manag initi is intend to make sure that it Level 4 offer is as complete, and as compelling, as possible. And your next new car might help.How Mobiley will build -- and profit from -- the mapsTh idea behind REM is that Mobiley can use the camera on exist car as a low-cost way to harvest the data need to make the maps, as well as other inform that will be use to self-driv cars. Mani new car have front-fac camera that are use for adapt cruis control, lane-departur warnings, and other advanc driver-assist system (or "ADAS") -- and mani of those camera-bas system were sold to the automak by Mobileye.In recent months, Mobiley ha been reach out to it automak clients, invit them to join the REM effort by allow data from their vehicl to be collected. In exchange, Mobiley is offer a share of the revenu it expect to gener from sell that data to mapmak companies.So far,Volkswagen AGandBMW AGhav sign up to allow REM to gather data from their vehicles, start in the 2018 model year. Duringthi past week' earn call, Mobileye' CTO Amnon Shashua said that hi compani expect to announc a third deal within a few weeks, and to have the major of it automak partner sign up by the end of 2017. (These deal includ extens privaci safeguards; the data won't be link to specif car owners.)Shashua explain how revenu will be gener from the REM effort:W believ revenu will be gener from two separ product [of REM]. One is the map, which is a critic input to autonom vehicl systems. The other is a broad set of real-tim dynam inform such as traffic density, weather condit and open park spots. We expect the primari custom for each of these product to be mapmakers, and we recent announc engag with both [high-definit map company] HERE and the Japanes map compani Zenrin.Th upshot: An import step as the self-driv race shape upAssum that a major of the world' major automak do in fact join the REM program, Mobileye' effort stand to put it ventur with Delphi and Intel in a strong competit posit as the market for self-driv system take shape.I'v argu that the idea of a "race" to self-driv technologyisn't a use way for investor to think. Level 4 system will be avail to all automak within four or five years; there won't be much advantag to the compani that come to market first. We won't be abl to think in term of "winners" until the detail of the differ offer becom clear.That process is starting. REM make it like that the Delphi-Mobileye-Intel offer will have access to map that allow it to oper in mani area of the world, right from the start. For investors, that make the success of the partners' system more likely, and an invest in Mobiley -- the purest play of the three -- a littl more compelling.10 stock we like better than MobileyeWhen invest genius David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip, it can pay to listen. After all, the newslett they have run for over a decade,Motley Fool Stock Advisor, ha tripl the market.*David and Tom just reveal what they believ are the10 best stocksfor investor to buy right now... and Mobiley wasn't one of them! That' right -- they think these 10 stock are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor return as of Februari 6, 2017Suzann Frey, an execut at Alphabet, is a member of The Motley Fool' board of directors.John Rosevearown share of Ford. column1: Is Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) In a Dividend Aristocrat Bubble?
column3: InvestorPlac - Stock Market News, Stock Advic & Trade TipsOn May 23, 1719, one of the greatest financi bubbl in the histori of the world kick off when the Compagni Perpetuel de Ind wa grant a monopoli by the French monarchi over all the trade right of all French coloni worldwide.makeArticleAd();Th company' stock price quickli soared, from 300 livr per share to more than 1,000 just a few month later. It wa quit a jump. But the enthusiasm continu for more than 18-months.In fact there wa such a frenzi to buy share that it wasn't uncommon for the stock price to doubl in a singl day. By November, share price had surpass 10,000.Base on modern-day calculations, a share price of 10,000 livr would have valu the compani at more than the entir GDP of Franc at the time.That would be likeAlphabet Inc(GOOGL) orAmazon.com, Inc.(AMZN) have a $20 TRILLION stock market capit today. Insane.A with all bubbl throughout history, that one burst as well… quickli and violently. Call it 'revers to the mean'. Stein' Law. Or just plain old common sense.It' pretti simple- there are certain anomali that are too absurd to last. And natur alway find a way to correct them.7 Dividend Stock for the Retir You DeserveWhil it' nowher near as extrem as the Compagni Perpetuel de Indes, the market today is also in a complet unsustain position.I'l show you what I mean-Tak a look atExxon Mobil Corporation(XOM); it' one of the largest compani in the world and a favorit among investor due to it 3.7% dividend yield.Quart after quarter, Exxon Mobil ha been pay dividend to it sharehold without fail for decades, even at the peak of the financi crisis.Not onli that, but the compani ha gener increas it dividend each year as well. To stock investors, that kind of consist is a gold mine. But there' a small problem.For the last sever years, Exxon ha been borrow money in order to maintain it dividend payments. Last month, for example, the compani report $26.4 billion in cashflow from it busi oper dure 2016.But in order to maintain the business, the compani had to spend $16.7 billion on what' known in financ as "capit expenditures" or "capex". Capex is critic to a big busi like Exxon Mobil; everi year they have to replac old machinery, purchas more land, etc.If they don't do these things, the busi will suffer and revenu will decline. So after subtract the capex, Exxon Mobil had $9.7 billion remain in "free cash flow".Not bad.Except that, accord to the company,they paid $12.5 billion in dividends.Hang on a sec. How is it possibl that the compani could pay $12.5 billion in dividend when they onli had $9.7 billion in free cash flow remain after the capex spending?Easy. They went into debt. Exxon borrow billion of dollar in order to pay it sharehold a healthi dividend. And they'v been do thi for years. Exxon Mobil is FAR from alone.Verizon Commun Inc.(VZ) is anoth shine example: in 2016, the compani earn $22.7 billion from it busi operations, but had $17.1 billion worth of capex. That left $5.6 billion remaining. Yet Verizon paid $9.3 billion in dividends.Onc again, the compani took on billion of dollar in addit debt.Thi ha been a major trend across the biggest compani in the market.There' noth wrong with debt; sometim it can be a smart move that creat valu for the company.Our manufactur busi in Australia recent took on some debt to buy some new equipment, for example. It' been a great decision; we'r abl to gener more revenu with less cost, so the overal growth in our profit is multipl greater than the interest payment.But borrow billion of dollar just to pay out what amount to sham dividend is a complet wast of money… and irresponsible.It also mean that these record high stock price are artificial, base on debt-fuel dividend and share buyback instead of healthi free cash flow.Thi is total unsustainable.In addition, with an averag P/E ratio of 26.5, stock valuat are at their highest level sinc the financi crisis; it' yet anoth layer of risk in thi market.10 Super-Saf Dividend Growth Stock to Buy TodayFew peopl ever got rich buy what wa popular and expensive. But that doesn't stop anyon from trying.Sometim the hardest thing to do is wait patient on the sidelines.But success peopl don't follow the crowd. They get out in front of the crowd, even if it mean be early.Th postDividend Aristocrat Bubble?appear first onValueWalk.Mani academ claim invest is a "random walk." We believ thi to be onli partial true. It is our core belief that valu invest can outperform the market, henc the name "ValueWalk." column1: Will Driverless Cars End Traditional Car Ownership?
column3: I bought a use car recently, and a few day after I brought it home, a friend ask me, "Do you think thi is the last car you'll ever buy?"W talk a lot about self-driv cars, so I knew exactli where he wa go with hi question. He wa hint at the fact that both autonom car technolog and ride-shar servic are advanc so quickli that by the time I'd be in the market for anoth vehicle, I might not actual need to buy one.Imag source: Getti Images.makeArticleAd();Bi 2035, the IH estim there will be 76 million car on the road worldwid with some level of autonomy.Even now, semi-autonom car that can keep themselv in their lanes, automat brake in emerg situations, and slow down to match the speed of the car in front of themcan be purchasedfor as littl as $20,000.And as genuin driverless car get cheaper and becom ubiquitous, you and I may opt out of monthli car payment and opt-in to a monthli mileag subscript servic instead.Automak are invest in thi futureTo understand how it' possibl that we could soon live in a world where most peopl don't own cars, we need to look no further than what the automak themselv are doing.Elon Musk' recent updat version ofTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) master plan includ detail on a new service: When the company' vehicl becom fulli autonom (bi 2018 or 2019, accord to Musk), Tesla owner will be abl to allow their vehicl to drive themselv around and be rent out by other people.A Musk wrote:Y will also be abl to add your car to the Tesla share fleet just by tap a button on the Tesla phone app and have it gener incom for you while you'r at work or on vacation, significantli offset and at time potenti exceed the monthli loan or leas cost.Imag source: Tesla.Musk also said that Tesla would deploy it own fleet of driverless vehicl for rent in area where there wa more demand for Tesla vehicl than privat own car could meet, so that "you can alway hail a ride from us no matter where you are." Remember, thi isn't the catchphras of a taxi company, nor even a ride-hail servic -- but rather the direct where Musk see hi automak headed.And just in case think thi mental is uniqu to the innov Tesla, consid whatGener Motors(NYSE: GM) is doing. The giant automak launch a ride-shar servic last year call Maven, which allow some GM owner to rent out their vehicl when they'r not in use. The car don't drive themselv yet, but the compani see it as a first step toward a futur where peopl are less inclin to own cars.In a press releas at the time, GM said that more than 25 million of it custom around the world will use some form of share mobil by 2020, and describ Maven as "a key element of our strategi to chang ownership model in the automot industry." Maven ha spread to 17 citi across North America in just 11 months, ha 22,000 members, and ha been use for 57 million mile of driving.Not to be outdone,Ford(NYSE: F) ha launch i ts own ride-shar service, and is develop autonom car just like GM. Ford ha made it clear that it intend to launch a "high-volume" driverless car pair with ride-hail and ride-shar servic by 2021. The compani is alreadi test 30 self-driv Fusion Hybrid in sever states, and plan to tripl the number of test vehicl thi year.Oth automak are move in thi direct as well.Fiat Chrysler(NYSE: FCAU) is work withAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Googl to test a fleet of 100 self-driv minivan that will be the basi for aride-hail serviceset to launch later thi year. It' still unclear what the servic will look like, or if Fiat Chrysler will play a critic role in it, but what is clear is that the automak believ in the viabil of Waymo' cars-as-a-servic goal.Wil thi realli end car ownership?It' hard to answer thi question conclusively, of course. After all, most peopl haven't even seen a fulli autonom vehicl on the road, let alon ridden in one.But John Zimmer, the co-found and presid of ride-hail compani Lyft,believ thatbi 2025 "privat car ownership will all-but end in major U.S. cities." Lyft expect the major of it vehicl to be self-driv by 2021, and rival Uber is test similar strategi as well.Oth have set similar timelin for the demis of car ownership. Georg Bauer, who ha held execut posit at Daimler, BMW, and TeslatoldBusi Insiderlast year that he think car ownership could be dead within five to 10 years.Govern regul and our own apprehens about give up control over our vehicl may preserv the widespread car ownership cultur for longer than some expect. But what' crystal clear is that tech compani and automak alik are bet on an automot futur that look veri differ than today. Like mani things, the transit from own car to rent driverless one on an as-need basi will like occur in stage -- but let' be clear, thing are certainli move in thi direction. And I, for one, would welcom a world without car payments.10 stock we like better than TeslaWhen invest genius David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip, it can pay to listen. column1: Warren Buffett Might Make These 3 Driverless Car Investing Mistakes

If everyon is use a specif product or platform, it can be extrem difficult for anoth compani to make inroads.At first glance, driverless car seem to be an excel opportun to build network effects. Instead, Waymo car are equip with sensor and softwar design to detect obstacl up to "two footbal field away in all directions." Ford, Alphabet, Tesla Motors, and other aren't interest in network effect in thi arena. They'r interest in their car have the most acut local-area awar they can contain.3. If onli one compani is abl to meet all the regulatori requir of be in a business, it' essenti illeg for other to tri to compet with it. The driverless car industri recogn this, and is make move to ensur a level play field for all involved.Alphabet, Ford, Lyft, Uber, and Volvo Car join togeth last April to creat the "Self-Driv Coalit for Safer Streets, " a lobbi group whose state mission is to "work with lawmakers, regulators, and the public to realiz the safeti and societ benefit of self-driv vehicles." These compani are interest in standard nation polici with simpl and low-cost barrier to entri for all interest automakers. So for Buffett fan look to back the compani with the strongest regulation-rel advantages, know that some of the biggest name in the busi are work proactiv to push polici that ensur no compani can ever build a regulatori moat.Pick the right self-driv car stockWarren Buffett is an incred investor, but he doesn't have answer for everi industry. column3: Gener Motors(NYSE: GM) is plan to build and deploy thousand of self-driv electr car in test fleet with Lyft next year, accord to a newReutersreport.If that' for real, it will be by far the largest fleet of autonom test vehicl in operation. column3: An IRA is a fantast retir save tool, but mani American don't take advantag of it, and when they do, they fail to make the most of it. If you'r among them, don't worry. Similarly, in order to contribut to a Roth IRA, your modifi adjust gross incom need to be below set limit too.Recently, fellow Motley Fool Matthew Frankel did a great job at explain adjust incom limit for IRA'shere, but in short, if you'r singl and you are cover by a retir plan at work, you can take the full deduct on a tradit IRA contribut if your adjust incom is below $62,000 in 2017. A partial contribut can be made if your incom is between $184,000 and $194,000.If you think you'r close to these limit and you'r unsur of how to calcul your modifi adjust gross income, you can read up on the subjecthere.How to invest in an IRAOnc you'v contribut to an IRA, you'll need to pick some investments. column1: Apple to Begin Assembling iPhone SE in India from April
column3: makeZacksArticleAd();Reportedly,Appl Inc.AAPLin collabor with it manufacturer, Wistron Inc. will begin to assembl iPhon SE in India start thi April. The plant will be locat in the state of Karnataka in south India.Though there is no offici word on the matter from Appl or Wistron, it ha been report that initi the Cupertino giant want to assembl 0.3-0.4 million unit of iPhon SE. Appl hasn't even wait for the numer tax concess that it sought from the India govern includ the 15-year custom duti holiday.Analyst observ that it wa prudent on part of Appl to begin assembl it most econom iPhon offering, SE, which wa launch to cater to cost sensit market like India. Plus, it also will support futur iO upgrad unlik iPhon 5S, which will soon be discontinu in most of the market includ India.Appl Inc. PriceAppl Inc. Price|Appl Inc. QuoteWhi is Appl Keen on India?Sinc the last year, Appl ha been increas it focu on India to claim a greater share of the vast smartphon market, of which it reportedli hold onli 2% as of now. Appl face slow iPhon demand in most of the regions, either becaus of competit or regulatori hurdl (China) or market satur (the U.S). Therefore, it make sens for the compani to solidifi it posit in India, which is project to becom the second largest smartphon market in the world. In fiscal 2016, Appl sale in India grew approxim 50% over the prior fiscal.Furthermore, a younger (and skilled) popul and increas invest in broadband network by the govern also make India an attract growth opportun for Appl over the long run. In fact, the govern under PM Narendra Modi is eager to bring foreign capit and boost manufactur facil in India.Th recent outlin FDI polici also bode well for the compani as it elimin the requir to local sourc product for at least a three-year period. Thi will enabl Appl to open it solely-own retail store in India. Thereafter, the compani will have to compli with the rule. The compani ha also partner with telecom compani Reliance, which is provid it Jio (a uniqu all-IP network) servic for free with the new iPhones.Last year, Tim Cook wa on a charm offens in India. Besid meet Modi, he also announc the open of an iO App Design and Develop Acceler in Bengaluru and a map develop offic in anoth southern Indian city, Hyderabad in collabor with region firm RMSI.ChallengesTh market is highli cost sensitive. Reportedly, major of the smartphon sold are price around INR 10K (roughli $145). iPhon 7 on the other hand cost almost five time more. Even iPhon SE is price at INR 30K. The lion' share of Apple' revenu in the countri come from devices, which are a coupl of gener old. Newer model have rel low demand given the hefti price tag. A few day back, it wa report that the Appl team in India is tri to increas revenu to $3 billion by 2017-18 and by local assembl operations, the compani can start to oper it own retail outlet and avail a 10% tax benefit. Thi should lower prices.Plus, Apple' rival Samsung along with a few Chines smartphon maker domin thi market. Samsung ha long been in the market and with reportedli 23% share, it is a lead player in the country. Appl is quit late to the party.Also, Apple' lack of focu on region customers' demand is a concern. India is categor by handset that work on dual SIMs. Apparently, Appl is not keen on make dual SIM handsets. Thi could be a veri big impedi to growth in the country.Also, analyst observ that Appl is "relocating" manufactur to India from China, given rise labor costs. Howev anoth analyst argu that though labor is cheap compar with China, product is rel better in China. Simpl assembl may not drastic bring down prices. However, the creation of a local suppli chain as in China will be a big positive.Despit the pro and cons, Appl is expect to continu it India drive. It will be take up a lot more initi thi year. However, whether those initi yield desir result remain a watch and see story.Apple, of course, is not the onli tech player eye India for growth. Given the potenti of thi market, Silicon Valley' interest is well understood. From Microsoft Corp.MSFTto AlphabetGOOGLto Facebook Inc.FBal remain laser focus on the market.Zack Rank & Price MovementAt present, Appl ha a Zack Rank #3 (Hold).
